case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Dewas Cine Corporation

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2163 of 1966 was filed before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 2163 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated April 15, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 22 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 15, 1964 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 22 of 1963.

facts.text: S.G. Sanghi and Hari Prasad entered into a partnership agreement as exhibitors of cinematograph films under the name Dewas Cine Corporation with effect from March 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: S.G. Sanghi and Hari Prasad entered into an agreement to carry on business in partnership as exhibitors of cinematograph films in the name and style of Dewas Cine Corporation with effect from March 1, 1947.

facts.text: Each partner brought his cinematograph theatre into the books of the partnership as an asset.

anchor.surface_text: Each partner who was an owner of a cinematograph theatre brought his theatre into the books of the partnership as an asset of the partnership.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer allowed depreciation aggregating to Rs. 44,380/- in respect of the two theatres for assessment years 1950-51 to 1952-53.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1950-51 to 1952-53 the Income-tax Officer allowed depreciation aggregating to Rs. 44,380/- in respect of the two theatres.

facts.text: The partnership was dissolved on September 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership was dissolved on September 30, 1951,

facts.text: On dissolution, partners agreed that the theatres should be returned to their original owners.

anchor.surface_text: and on dissolution it was agreed between the partners, that the theatres should be returned to their original owners.

facts.text: In the partnership books, assets were shown as taken over on October 1, 1951 at original price less depreciation allowed, with depreciation equally divided between partners.

anchor.surface_text: In the books of account maintained by the partnership, the assets were shown as taken over on October 1, 1951 at the original price less the depreciation allowed the depreciation being equally divided between the two partners.

facts.text: For assessment year 1952-53, the respondent was treated as a registered firm.

anchor.surface_text: In proceedings for assessment for the year 1952-53 the respondent was treated as a registered firm.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that restoring theatres to original owners constituted a transfer by the firm and entries amounted to recoupment of depreciation, applying proviso 2 to s. 10(2)(vii) of Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held that by restoring the two theatres to the two original owners there was a transfer by the firm and the entries adjusting the depreciation and writing off the assets at the original value amounted to total recoupment of the entire depreciation by the partnership and on that account proviso 2 to s. 10 2  vii  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, applied.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court answered the referred question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Madhya Pradesh answered the following question referred to it by the Tribunal the negative

facts.text: The question referred was: Whether on the facts and circumstances, Rs. 44,380/- was rightly included in total income of assessee for 1952-53 under second proviso to s. 10(2)(vii) of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the amount of Rs. 44,380/- was rightly included in the total income of the assessee in the year 1952-53 under the second proviso to s. 10 2   vii  of the Income-tax Act ?

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax appealed to Supreme Court with certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court with certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Depreciation was allowed by taxing authorities in respect of each theatre in assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In respect of each of the theatres depreciation was allowed by the taxing authorities in proceedings for assessment.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal viewed that theatres were sold to partners upon dissolution.

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Appellate Tribunal was of the view that since the theatres were returned to the partners in settling the accounts of the partners on dissolution, the theatres were in law sold to the partners.

facts.text: High Court disagreed with Tribunal's view that theatres were sold.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court disagreed with that view.

facts.text: The two partners brought their theatres into the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership.

facts.text: On dissolution, each theatre was returned to the original owner in satisfaction of his share in residue assets.

anchor.surface_text: On dissolution of the partnership, each theatre must be deemed to be returned to the original owner, in satisfaction partially or wholly of his claim to a share in the residue of the assets after discharging the debts and other obligations.

facts.text: Counsel for Revenue argued that allotment of property to partners constitutes notional sale.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing for the Revenue submitted that each partner is entitled to have the assets of the partnership sold for discharging the debts and obligations of the partnership, and for the. purpose of dividing the residue among the partners if property is allotted to the partners in satisfaction of their claims, the transaction must be deemed in law to take the form of a numberional sale of the property to the partner in companysideration of the money value of his share.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.
proviso 2 to s. 10 2  vii  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, applied.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provides that where sale price exceeds written down value, excess up to original cost minus WDV is deemed profit

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the amount of Rs. 44,380/- was rightly included in the total income of the assessee in the year 1952-53 under the second proviso to s. 10(2)(vii) of the Income-tax Act?

anchor.surface_text: the negative Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the amount of Rs. 44,380/- was rightly included in the total income of the assessee in the year 1952-53 under the second proviso to s. 10 2   vii  of the Income-tax Act ?

issues.text: Whether the theatres were in law sold to the partners upon being returned to them on dissolution of the partnership

anchor.surface_text: The Income- tax Appellate Tribunal was of the view that since the theatres were returned to the partners in settling the accounts of the partners on dissolution, the theatres were in law sold to the partners.

issues.text: Whether the distribution of partnership assets to partners on dissolution amounts to a sale or transfer of property for a price under s. 10(2)(vii)

anchor.surface_text: On dissolution of the partnership, each theatre must be deemed to be returned to the original owner, in satisfaction partially or wholly of his claim to a share in the residue of the assets after discharging the debts and other obligations. But thereby the theaters were number in law sold by the partnership to the individual partners in companysideration of their respective share in the residue. The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does number amount to transfer of assets.

issues.text: Whether allotment of partnership property to a partner in satisfaction of their claim constitutes a notional sale

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing for the Revenue submitted that each partner is entitled to have the assets of the partnership sold for discharging the debts and obligations of the partnership, and for the. purpose of dividing the residue among the partners if property is allotted to the partners in satisfaction of their claims, the transaction must be deemed in law to take the form of a numberional sale of the property to the partner in companysideration of the money value of his share.

arguments.claim: By restoring the two theatres to the two original owners there was a transfer by the firm and the entries adjusting the depreciation and writing off the assets at the original value amounted to total recoupment of the entire depreciation by the partnership and on that account proviso 2 to s. 10(2)(vii) of Income-tax Act, 1922, applied.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership was dissolved on September 30, 1951, and on dissolution it was agreed between the partners, that the theatres should be returned to their original owners. In the books of account maintained by the partnership, the assets were shown as taken over on October 1, 1951 at the original price less the depreciation allowed the depreciation being equally divided between the two partners. In proceedings for assessment for the year 1952-53 the respondent was treated as a registered firm. The Appellate Tribunal held that by restoring the two theatres to the two original owners there was a transfer by the firm and the entries adjusting the depreciation and writing off the assets at the original value amounted to total recoupment of the entire depreciation by the partnership and on that account proviso 2 to s. 10 2  vii  of the Income-tax Act, 1922, applied.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: Court with certificate granted by the High Court. Section 10 2  of the Income-tax Act permits certain allowances to be debited in the companyputation

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agreed no sale occurred triggering the proviso.

arguments.claim: If property is allotted to the partners in satisfaction of their claims, the transaction must be deemed in law to take the form of a notional sale of the property to the partner in consideration of the money value of his share.

anchor.surface_text: The Solicitor-General appearing for the Revenue submitted that each partner is entitled to have the assets of the partnership sold for discharging the debts and obligations of the partnership, and for the. purpose of dividing the residue among the partners if property is allotted to the partners in satisfaction of their claims, the transaction must be deemed in law to take the form of a notional sale of the property to the partner in consideration of the money value of his share. Counsel relied upon the statement of the law in Lindley on Partnership, 12th Edn., at p. 568 in the absence of a special agreement to the contrary, the right of each partner on a dissolution is to have the partnership property converted into money by a sale, even although a sale may not be necessary for the payment of debts., and also upon the decision of this Court in Addanki Narayanappa and another v. Bhaskara Krishnappa and others 1 .

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does number amount to transfer of assets. On dissolution of the partnership, each theatre must be

arguments.court_reasoning: Sale requires transfer of property for a price; adjustment of partners' rights in dissolved firm is neither a transfer nor for a price.

arguments.claim: Property brought into the partnership by partners becomes the property of the partnership; theatres must be deemed to have become property of the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Partnership Act, 1932, property which is brought into the partnership by the partners when it is formed or which may be acquired in the course of the business becomes the property of the partnership and a partner is, subject to any special agreement between the partners, entitled upon dissolution to a share in the money representing the value of the property. When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership.

arguments.claim: Under s. 46 of Partnership Act, 1932, on dissolution every partner is entitled to have firm property applied to debts and surplus distributed according to rights.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 46 of the Partnership Act, 1932, on the dissolution of-the firm every partner or his representative is entitled, as against all the other partners or their representatives, to have the property of the firm applied in payment of the debts and liabilities of the firm, and to have the surplus distributed among the partners or their representatives according to their rights.

arguments.claim: Section 48 of Partnership Act provides mode of settlement of accounts; residue divided between partners.

anchor.surface_text: Section 48 of the Partnership Act provides for the mode of settlement of accounts between the partners. It prescribes the sequence in which the various outgoing are to be applied and. the residue remaining is to be divided between the partners.

arguments.claim: On dissolution, each theatre deemed returned to original owner in satisfaction of share in residue, but not sold by partnership to partners.

anchor.surface_text: On dissolution of the partnership, each theatre must be deemed to be returned to the original owner, in satisfaction partially or wholly of his claim to a share in the residue of the assets after discharging the debts and other obligations. But thereby the theaters were not in law sold by the partnership to the individual partners in consideration of their respective share in the residue.

arguments.claim: The distribution of surplus is adjustment of rights of partners in assets; does not amount to transfer of assets.

anchor.surface_text: The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does not amount to transfer of assets.

arguments.claim: Expressions 'sale' and 'sold' in s.10(2)(vii) bear ordinary meaning: transfer of property for a price; partners' rights adjustment is neither.

anchor.surface_text: The expressions sale and sold are not defined in the Income-tax Act-those expressions are used in s. 10 2  vii  in their ordinary meaning. Sale, according to its ordinary meaning is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm is not a transfer, nor it is for a price.

holdings.text: When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership.

anchor.surface_text: When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying Partnership Act, 1932 principles that property brought into partnership becomes firm property.

holdings.text: On dissolution of the partnership, each theatre must be deemed to be returned to the original owner, in satisfaction partially or wholly of his claim to a share in the residue of the assets after discharging the debts and other obligations.

anchor.surface_text: On dissolution of the partnership, each theatre must be deemed to be returned to the original owner, in satisfaction partially or wholly of his claim to a share in the residue of the assets after discharging the debts and other obligations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under ss. 46 and 48 of Partnership Act, 1932, partners entitled to surplus distribution via adjustment of firm property.

holdings.text: But thereby the theaters were not in law sold by the partnership to the individual partners in consideration of their respective share in the residue. The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does not amount to transfer of assets.

anchor.surface_text: But thereby the theaters were not in law sold by the partnership to the individual partners in consideration of their respective share in the residue. The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does not amount to transfer of assets.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distribution on dissolution adjusts inter se rights under Partnership Act, not a transfer.

holdings.text: The expressions sale and sold are not defined in the Income-tax Act-those expressions are used in s. 10(2)(vii) in their ordinary meaning. Sale, according to its ordinary meaning is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm is not a transfer, nor it is for a price.

anchor.surface_text: The expressions sale and sold are not defined in the Income-tax Act-those expressions are used in s. 10 2  vii  in their ordinary meaning. Sale, according to its ordinary meaning is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm is not a transfer, nor it is for a price.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'sale' and 'sold' in s.10(2)(vii); rejects notional sale argument as ordinary meaning requires price consideration.

holdings.text: Rs. 44,380/- was not rightly included in the total income of the assessee for 1952-53 under the second proviso to s. 10(2)(vii) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: the negative Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the amount of Rs. 44,380/- was rightly included in the total income of the assessee in the year 1952-53 under the second proviso to s. 10 2   vii  of the Income-tax Act ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: No sale or transfer occurred on dissolution; proviso requires actual sale exceeding WDV, which adjustment of partners' rights does not constitute.

anchor.surface_text: Addanki Narayanappa and another v. Bhaskara Krishnappa and others 1

precedents.cited_proposition: the right of each partner on a dissolution is to have the partnership property converted into money by a sale, even although a sale may not be necessary for the payment of debts

justification_sets.label: Partnership Act, 1932 (general principles on partnership property) support
Proviso 2 to Section 10(2)(vii) of Income-tax Act, 1922 support

anchor.surface_text: Under the Partnership Act, 1932, property which is brought into the partnership by the partners when it is formed or which may be acquired in the companysrse of the business becomes the property of the partnership and a partner is, subject to any special agreement between the partners, entitled upon dissolution to a share in the money representing the value of the property. When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership. Under s. 46 of the Partnership Act, 1932, on the dissolution of-the firm every partner or his representative is entitled, as against all the other partners or their representatives, to have the property of the firm applied in payment of the debts and liabilities of the firm, and to have the surplus distributed among the partners or their representatives according to their rights. Section 48 of the Partnership Act provides for the mode of settlement of accounts between the partners. It prescribes the sequence in which the various outgoing are to be applied and. the residue remaining is to be divided between the partners. The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does number amount to transfer of assets.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Partnership Act, 1932, property which is brought into the partnership by the partners when it is formed or which may be acquired in the companysrse of the business becomes the property of the partnership and a partner is, subject to any special agreement between the partners, entitled upon dissolution to a share in the money representing the value of the property. When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership. Under s. 46 of the Partnership Act, 1932, on the dissolution of-the firm every partner or his representative is entitled, as against all the other partners or their representatives, to have the property of the firm applied in payment of the debts and liabilities of the firm, and to have the surplus distributed among the partners or their representatives according to their rights. Section 48 of the Partnership Act provides for the mode of settlement of accounts between the partners. It prescribes the sequence in which the various outgoing are to be applied and. the residue remaining is to be divided between the partners. The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does number amount to transfer of assets.

anchor.surface_text: The expressions sale and sold are not defined in the Income-tax Act-those expressions are used in s. 10 2  vii  in their ordinary meaning. Sale, according to its ordinary meaning is a transfer of property for a price, and adjustment of the rights of the partners in a dissolved firm is not a transfer, nor it is for a price.

Under the Partnership Act, 1932, property which is brought into the partnership by the partners when it is formed or which may be acquired in the companysrse of the business becomes the property of the partnership and a partner is, subject to any special agreement between the partners, entitled upon dissolution to a share in the money representing the value of the property. When the two partners brought in the theatres of their respective ownership into the partnership, the theatres must be deemed to have become the property of the partnership. Under s. 46 of the Partnership Act, 1932, on the dissolution of-the firm every partner or his representative is entitled, as against all the other partners or their representatives, to have the property of the firm applied in payment of the debts and liabilities of the firm, and to have the surplus distributed among the partners or their representatives according to their rights. Section 48 of the Partnership Act provides for the mode of settlement of accounts between the partners. It prescribes the sequence in which the various outgoing are to be applied and. the residue remaining is to be divided between the partners. The distribution of surplus is for the purpose of adjustment of the rights of the partners in the assets of the partnership it does number amount to transfer of assets.
